moves.2... dxc4 3. Nc3 Bd7: Black can't actually hold on to the gambit pawn.  It's usually worse to try because White normally regains it under favorable circumstances.
moves.6... Bc6: Although this threatens the g2 pawn, the threat is easily met with normal development.  c6 is not a great square for the B and it wastes a tempo.
moves.7. Nf3 Bb4 8. O-O Bxc3 9. bxc3 O-O 10. Q: White gets the N to a good square with the gain of a tempo.
Black's development is lagging because of the loss of time earlier.
moves.16... b6 17. Bxe4 Nxe4 18. c4: Nc3 for Black looks like it forks the Q and R, but after Qa3+ the N is lost.
moves.19. Qc2 f5 20. f3: f3 kicks the N from a good square.  Note that Black cannot kick White's N with a pawn after playing f5.
moves.21... axb6 22. Rxa8: This also wins the N, which Black realizes too late.
moves.22... Qc8 23. Rxb8: If Qxb2, Nd7+ wins the Q.
moves.23... Qxb8: Black resigned right after this capture when they realized Nd7 would be crushing.
